summary.para: Abstract event produced by a command. Use pattern matching to handle specific instances of this type.

member.name: T:CliWrap.PipeTarget
member.summary: Abstraction that represents an outwards-facing pipe.

member.name: M:CliWrap.PipeTarget.CopyFromAsync(System.IO.Stream,System.Threading.CancellationToken)
member.summary: Reads the binary content from the origin stream and pushes it into the pipe. Origin stream represents the process's standard output or standard error stream.

member.name: P:CliWrap.PipeTarget.Null
member.summary: Pipe target that discards all data. Functionally equivalent to a null device.
member.remarks: Using this target results in the corresponding stream (standard output or standard error) not being opened for the underlying process at all. In the vast majority of cases, this behavior should be functionally equivalent to piping to a null stream, but without the performance overhead of consuming and discarding unneeded data. This may be undesirable in certain situations â€” in which case it's recommended to pipe to a null stream explicitly using with .

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that the method or property will ensure that the listed field and property members have not-null values.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullAttribute.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Initializes the attribute with a field or property member.
member.param: The field or property member that is promised to be not-null.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullAttribute.#ctor(System.String[])
member.summary: Initializes the attribute with the list of field and property members.
member.param: The list of field and property members that are promised to be not-null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullAttribute.Members
member.summary: Gets field or property member names.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullWhenAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that the method or property will ensure that the listed field and property members have not-null values when returning with the specified return value condition.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullWhenAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.String)
member.summary: Initializes the attribute with the specified return value condition and a field or property member.
member.param: The return value condition. If the method returns this value, the associated parameter will not be null.
The field or property member that is promised to be not-null.

member.name: M:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullWhenAttribute.#ctor(System.Boolean,System.String[])
member.summary: Initializes the attribute with the specified return value condition and list of field and property members.
member.param: The return value condition. If the method returns this value, the associated parameter will not be null.
The list of field and property members that are promised to be not-null.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullWhenAttribute.ReturnValue
member.summary: Gets the return value condition.

member.name: P:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.MemberNotNullWhenAttribute.Members
member.summary: Gets field or property member names.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.SetsRequiredMembersAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that this constructor sets all required members for the current type, and callers do not need to set any required members themselves.

member.name: T:System.Diagnostics.CodeAnalysis.UnscopedRefAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate a byref escapes and is not scoped.

remarks.para: There are several cases where the C# compiler treats a as implicitly - where the compiler does not allow the to escape the method.

For example:
for instance methods.
parameters that refer to types.
parameters.
This attribute is used in those instances where the should be allowed to escape.

Applying this attribute, in any form, has impact on consumers of the applicable API. It is necessary for API authors to understand the lifetime implications of applying this attribute and how it may impact their users.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.IsExternalInit
member.summary: Reserved to be used by the compiler for tracking metadata. This class should not be used by developers in source code.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.ModuleInitializerAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that a method should be called in its containing module's initializer.
member.remarks:
When one or more valid methods with this attribute are found in a compilation, the compiler will emit a module initializer which calls each of the attributed methods.
Certain requirements are imposed on any method targeted with this attribute: - The method must be `static`. - The method must be an ordinary member method, as opposed to a property accessor, constructor, local function, etc. - The method must be parameterless. - The method must return `void`. - The method must not be generic or be contained in a generic type. - The method's effective accessibility must be `internal` or `public`.
The specification for module initializers in the .NET runtime can be found here: https://github.com/dotnet/runtime/blob/main/docs/design/specs/Ecma-335-Augments.md#module-initializer

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.RequiredMemberAttribute
member.summary: Specifies that a type has required members or that a member is required.

member.name: T:System.Runtime.CompilerServices.SkipLocalsInitAttribute
member.summary: Used to indicate to the compiler that the .locals init flag should not be set in method headers.
